description: 1765 as noun, 1818 as adjective, from Medieval Latin fungibilis, from Latin fungor (“I perform, I discharge a duty”) (English function)  +‎ -ible (“able to”). Originally a legal term, going back to Roman law: res fungibilis (“replaceable things”).

adjectives.description: fungible (comparative more fungible, superlative most fungible)

entries.meaning: (finance and commerce) Able to be substituted for something of equal value or utility.
(chiefly in the plural) Any fungible item.
